title: why i always looking for peer
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `1.10.17`
OS & Version: Linux
Commit hash : (if `develop`)

#### Expected behaviour


#### Actual behaviour
at first, i was normal to sync, but i don't know why when i sync the latest block, it look like stuck, and always looking for peers, i had try restart it, but not work, still always looking for peers

```
ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:11:12.661] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1    txs=51   mgas=22.200   elapsed=75.195ms  mgasps=295.224  number=6,634,052 hash=754f30..7af106 dirty=222.67MiB
ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:11:13.726] Chain reorg detected                     number=6,634,051 hash=ea49f6..1a1f3b drop=1 dropfrom=754f30..7af106 add=1 addfrom=ab8e39..3441d5
ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:11:13.727] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1    txs=49   mgas=17.995   elapsed=73.383ms  mgasps=245.214  number=6,634,052 hash=ab8e39..3441d5 dirty=222.70MiB
ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:11:14.270] Chain reorg detected                     number=6,634,051 hash=ea49f6..1a1f3b drop=1 dropfrom=ab8e39..3441d5 add=1 addfrom=0f908d..96f768

ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:11:26.576] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1    txs=53   mgas=14.382   elapsed=63.435ms  mgasps=226.715  number=6,634,053 hash=7b70ad..3c6615 dirty=222.83MiB
ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:11:31.252] Looking for peers                        peercount=2 tried=4 static=0

ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:50:33.531] Looking for peers                        peercount=0 tried=2 static=0
```
Could you paste your startup command? It's not easy for geth to find suitable peers, especially on non-mainnet networks

> Could you paste your startup command? It's not easy for geth to find suitable peers, especially on non-mainnet networks

ok, this is my startup command `geth --goerli --syncmode=full --http --http.addr=0.0.0.0 --http.port=8546 --http.vhosts=* --port 30304 --http.api web3,eth,net,debug,personal,txpool --txlookuplimit=0 --datadir /app/goerli/.ethereum`

There's a strange gap here:
```
ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:13:51.267] Looking for peers                        peercount=0 tried=2 static=0
ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:48:23.519] Looking for peers                        peercount=0 tried=3 static=0
```
Did you intentionally clip together two different snippets of logs, or did it actually just behave like this?

> There's a strange gap here:
> 
> ```
> ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:13:51.267] Looking for peers                        peercount=0 tried=2 static=0
> ethereum_goerli_test_net_1   | INFO [03-31|15:48:23.519] Looking for peers                        peercount=0 tried=3 static=0
> ```
> 
> Did you intentionally clip together two different snippets of logs, or did it actually just behave like this?

because from 15:13 to 15:48 are all log `INFO:Looking for peers`, but after 15:48, it have log some new message

I see. Well, one thing that might tell us more is if you enable loglevel trace (for a brief while). That spits out a whole lot of information, and what we're most interested in would be information related to the discovery. 

You can increase the verbosity via api. `debug.verbosity(5)`. A few hundred lines would be good (and preferrably not directly after startup, but after it has had a chance to run for a while)

> You can increase the verbosity via api. `debug.verbosity(5)`. A few hundred lines would be good (and preferrably not directly after startup, but after it has had a chance to run for a while)

here is my logs after use `debug.verbosity(5)`
```

And right _before_ those semi-successfull ping/pongs, there are these errors: 
```
TRACE[04-01|17:16:38.371] Accepted connection                      addr=167.86.103.114:34856
TRACE[04-01|17:16:38.372] Failed RLPx handshake                    addr=167.86.103.114:34856  conn=inbound err="ecies: invalid message"
```

> And right _before_ those semi-successfull ping/pongs, there are these errors:

so, what should i do with the `unknow node` and `invalid message`

These are misbehaving peers. We would expect the following: 
```
<< PING
>> PONG
>> PING
<< PONG
<< FINDNODE
```

It could also be a routing problem, where the outgoing `>> PING` is not received by the remote peer, or the `<< PONG` is sent to the wrong destination or dropped.
@lpf763827726 Can you share your Dockerfile?
also: do you face the same problems if you run the node outside docker?
@blockchaindevsh this issue is not about frequent EOF.

> @lpf763827726 Can you share your Dockerfile?

sure

Dockerfile:
```
FROM debian:latest

RUN apt-get update -y
RUN apt-get upgrade -y
RUN apt-get install -y gcc
RUN apt-get install -y manpages-dev
RUN apt-get install -y wget

RUN wget https://dl.google.com/go/go1.17.7.linux-amd64.tar.gz
RUN tar -zxvf go1.17.7.linux-amd64.tar.gz -C /
ENV GOPATH=/go GOPROXY=https://goproxy.cn PATH=$PATH:/go/bin:$GOPATH/bin

RUN go install github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/cmd/geth@latest

EXPOSE 8546
EXPOSE 30304

WORKDIR /app

ADD start.sh /app/start.sh

ENTRYPOINT ["/app/start.sh"]
```

docker-compose.yaml:
```
version: "3"

services:
   ethereum_goerli_test_net:
     image: gitlab.******.xyz:5050/ethereum-chain:dev
     volumes:
       - /mnt/bigstore/ethereum_full:/app/goerli
     environment: 
       NET: goerli
       SYNCMODE: full
       HTTP_PORT: 8546
       PORT: 30304
       DIR: /app/goerli
     ports:
       - "8546:8546"
       - "30304:30304"
     networks:
       - chains-net

   ethereum_mainnet:
     image: gitlab.******.xyz:5050/ethereum-chain:dev
     volumes:
       - /mnt/ssd/chains/ethereum_mainnet:/app/mainnet
     environment:
       NET: mainnet
       SYNCMODE: full
       HTTP_PORT: 8646
       PORT: 30305
       DIR: /app/mainnet
     ports:
       - "8646:8646"
       - "30305:30305"
     networks:
       - chains-net

networks:
  chains-net:
    driver: bridge
```

start.sh:
```
#!/bin/bash

geth --$NET --syncmode=$SYNCMODE --http --http.addr=0.0.0.0 --http.port=$HTTP_PORT --http.vhosts=* --port $PORT --http.api web3,eth,net,debug,personal,txpool --txlookuplimit=0 --datadir $DIR
```

> also: do you face the same problems if you run the node outside docker?

no, i used to run it in geth in my computer, it's all highest block, i run it in docker because i want to start it in my 2 server, i think run it in docker may will be simple
Isn't the correct way to expose udp `EXPOSE 30304/udp` ?

Yes, one issue with this dockerfile is, the UDP port is not exposed.

You need to add `EXPOSE 30304/udp` in Dockerfile and `- "30304:30304/udp"` in docker-compose.yaml
(also, the start script uses `$PORT` but the dockerfile does not, so it's unclear which port it will actually listen on)

> Yes, one issue with this dockerfile is, the UDP port is not exposed.
> 
> You need to add `EXPOSE 30304/udp` in Dockerfile and `- "30304:30304/udp"` in docker-compose.yaml

mean i only need `EXPOSE 30304/udp` not need `EXPOSE 30304`?

You need both.

Dockerfile:

```
EXPOSE 30304/tcp 30304/udp
EXPOSE 8546/tcp
```

docker-compose.yaml:

```
services:
   ...
      ports:
         # peer to peer
         - "30304:30304/tcp"
         - "30304:30304/udp"
         # RPC
         - "8646:8646"
```

> You need both.
> 
> Dockerfile:
> 
> ```
> EXPOSE 30304/tcp 30304/udp
> EXPOSE 8546/tcp
> ```
> 
> docker-compose.yaml:
> 
> ```
> services:
>    ...
>       ports:
>          # peer to peer
>          - "30304:30304/tcp"
>          - "30304:30304/udp"
>          # RPC
>          - "8646:8646"
> ```

oh! it look work! thanks so much
Awesome!
